text: <@U2Y2V95D2> Hi. As far as I know, access control is not supported in v0.5 and v0.6. You can implement the access control in your chaincode using TCert Attribute.  <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/API/AttributesUsage.md>
quick question: how to enable TRACE option in membersrvc?

# Please see fabric/docs/Setup/logging-control.md for more options.
    server: warning
    ca: warning
    eca: warning
    ecap: warning
    ecaa: warning
    aca: warning
    acap: warning
    tca: warning
    tcap: warning
I see this `18:00:46.663 [logging] LoggingInit -> WARN 005 Logging level 'trace' not recognized, defaulting to INFO : logger: invalid log level`

[Resolved directly with Ramesh. That version of the code expected 
"CRITICAL",
    "ERROR",
    "WARNING",
    "NOTICE",
    "INFO",
    "DEBUG”,
and switched from TRACE to INFO]
Dear all, Question 1:  do we have a standby "membership-services? I mean membership service is always a single point of failure now? Thanks.
<@U2Y2V95D2>: you can (already) implement an application level Access Control, e.g., as described here <https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tech/application-ACL/>
As for the Single Point of Failure (… aka FUaD), what exactly do you mean?

You can have more than one process of Membership Services running, and divide the control/responsibility of the granting of privileges (that is, issuing certificates) using different processes already.
Don’t get me wrong - v1.0 will be richer in features, but there’s a lot you/we can already do with the existing code that’s out there.

I started a membersrvc on one VM, and an nv peer on another  VM,  some error occured , anyone can help?
Failed checking signing enrollment certificate for signing: [x509: certificate has expired or is not yet valid]
it just fine  when run on the same VM.
Because the machine time is not the same as the above problems.
